> > ... David, why do you think using constraints

>=
 Constraint in JMock has two abstract methods: eval and describeTo.
> Descr=
ibe is really cool, because it allows, basically for free, error

 like:
>
> junit.framework.AssertionFailedError:
> Expected: not (eq(<a bad=
 sentence>) or a string containing "a bad word")
> but got : This is a bad =
word

lementing class. I'm still split on whether this is worth it.

ctually a lot different than saying "Constraints are heavy

y be the same thing as saying "it's not yet quite clear

Do you mean that constraints 'double the amo=
unt of work for each
implementing class' because you have to implement two =
methods instead of
one? If so, I don't think that this is much of a problem=
 since you won't
write new constraints too often - their power comes from t=
